### Study 18: LINER Diagnostic Classification
**Citation**: Frontiers (2017) - "The AGN Nature of LINER Nuclear Sources"
**Authors**: Multiple
**Paper**: https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/astronomy-and-space-sciences/articles/10.3389/fspas.2017.00034/full

**Problem Statement**:
LINER (Low-Ionization Nuclear Emission-line Region) classification ambiguous: some are low-luminosity AGN, others ionized by shocks or evolved stars.

**Methodology**:
- BPT diagrams with LINER-specific boundaries
- WHAN diagram (new diagnostic): [NII]/Hα vs. Hα equivalent width
- Distinguishes AGN ionization from shock ionization and post-AGB stars
- Multiwavelength follow-up: X-ray, radio, infrared

**Key Dataset**:
- SDSS spectroscopy (~1/3 of local galaxies are LINERs)
- X-ray observations (Chandra) for subset
- Radio observations for jet detection
- Local AGN population (z < 0.1)

**Primary Results**:
1. LINERs represent heterogeneous population
2. Some are low-luminosity AGN (accretion-powered)
3. Others are shock-ionized (supernovae, winds)
4. Still others ionized by evolved stars (post-AGB)
5. WHAN diagram cleanly separates ionization sources

**Quantitative Results**:
- LINER prevalence: ~1/3 of nearby galaxies
- AGN-ionized LINER fraction: ~30-50% (estimates vary)
- Shock-ionized fraction: ~30-40%
- Post-AGB ionized: ~10-20%

**WHAN Diagram Boundaries**:
- Seyfert AGN: high [NII]/Hα, low Hα EW
- AGN-ionized LINER: high [NII]/Hα, intermediate Hα EW
- Shock-ionized LINER: variable [NII]/Hα, high Hα EW
- HII regions: low [NII]/Hα

**Stated Limitations**:
1. Some sources fall in ambiguous zones
2. Composite regions (SF + AGN) difficult to separate
3. AGN accretion rate/power for LINER subset unclear
4. Post-AGB contribution model-dependent

**Significance**:
Provides tools to identify true AGN within LINER population; crucial for AGN demographics at low luminosities.

## SECTION 7: AGN VARIABILITY AND REVERBERATION MAPPING

### Study 19: UV-X-ray Variability Disconnect
**Citation**: MNRAS 530, 4850 (2024) - "What drives the variability in AGN? Explaining the UV-Xray disconnect through propagating fluctuations"
**Authors**: Multiple
**Paper**: https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article/530/4/4850/7663594

**Problem Statement**:
X-ray reverberation model predicts UV should follow X-ray with short time lag. Observations show only weak UV-X-ray correlation.

**Methodology**:
- Multi-wavelength light curve monitoring: X-ray (Swift), UV (Swift UVOT), optical (ground-based)
- Lag analysis: cross-correlation function
- Power spectral density comparison
- Accretion physics modeling: disk response to variable X-ray illumination

**Key Dataset**:
- Swift/XRT X-ray observations (frequent cadence)
- Swift/UVOT UV observations (coincident with X-ray)
- Ground-based optical monitoring (V, R, I bands)
- Multiple AGN sample (Seyfert 1s, quasars)

**Primary Results**:
1. UV-X-ray correlation much weaker than expected
2. X-ray variability timescale: < 1 day
3. Optical variability timescale: 20-40 days
4. UV lags observed at 1-10 day timescale but not strictly correlated
5. X-ray reverberation model incomplete

**Quantitative Results**:
- X-ray RMS variability amplitude: ~30-50% on day timescale
- UV RMS variability: ~10-30% on week timescale
- Optical RMS variability: ~5-15% on month timescale
- UV-X-ray lag range: 1-10 days
- UV-X-ray correlation coefficient: ρ ~ 0.3-0.6 (weak)
- Optical-X-ray correlation: even weaker

**Possible Explanations**:
1. Non-linear disk response (saturation effects)
2. Multiple variability mechanisms (disk instabilities, magnetic reconnection)
3. Geometry effects (inclination-dependent)
4. Disk-corona coupling more complex than assumed

**Stated Limitations**:
1. Limited sample for population statistics
2. Redshift effects require k-correction
3. Dust reddening complicates optical-UV comparison
4. GRMHD simulations needed for detailed predictions

**Significance**:
Shows X-ray reverberation model inadequate; motivates more sophisticated disk-corona coupling models andadditional observations.

### Study 20: X-ray Reverberation Mapping
**Citation**: A&A 683, A18 (2024) - "X-ray reverberation modelling of the continuum, optical/UV time-lags in quasars"
**Authors**: Multiple
**Paper**: https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2024/11/aa50652-24/aa50652-24.html

**Problem Statement**:
Can X-ray reverberation (direct illumination + reflected photons) explain observed continuum and optical lags?

**Methodology**:
- X-ray reverberation model: direct illumination + disk reflection
- Spectral synthesis: compute reflected photons
- Time-domain modeling: convolve with illuminating flux variations
- Comparison to reverberation mapping campaigns

**Key Dataset**:
- Multi-wavelength reverberation mapping data
- XMM-Newton X-ray observations
- Swift UV/optical monitoring
- Quasar and Seyfert sample

**Primary Results**:
1. Direct X-ray illumination produces UV/optical lags
2. Lag magnitude depends on disk geometry and opacity
3. Model can explain some observed lags
4. Does not fully explain observed variability timescales
5. Suggests additional mechanisms operative

**Quantitative Results**:
- Predicted UV/optical lags: 1-10 days (matches observations for some AGN)
- Lag wavelength dependence: increases with wavelength (expected)
- UV color variation: follows from temperature change
- Efficiency of disk heating: ~10-50% of incident X-rays

**Stated Limitations**:
1. Simplified disk geometry
2. Magnetic field/viscosity effects neglected
3. Multiple scattering effects omitted
4. AGN sample limited

**Significance**:
Shows X-ray reverberation contributes to lags; but other mechanisms also important.

## Conclusion

This document extracted detailed research findings from 65+ papers spanning 20+ years of AGN multi-wavelength observations. Key recent advances (2023-2025) include warm corona physics recognition, accretion disk instability confirmation, and jets in radio-quiet AGN. Identified gaps include UV-X-ray variability mechanism, soft X-ray excess origin alternatives, and high-z AGN physics. Future work will benefit from JWST rest-frame spectroscopy, next-generation X-ray missions (AXIS, AMXT), and infrared interferometry.

### 1. Warm Corona and Soft X-Ray Excess
**Title**: "Unveiling energy pathways in AGN accretion flows with the warm corona model for the soft excess"
**Citation**: MNRAS 530, 1603 (2024)

**Key Results**: T = 0.1-1 keV, τ = 10-40, dissipative heating mechanism
**Link**: https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article/530/2/1603/7640859

### 2. Accretion Disk Instability Confirmation
**Title**: "Systematic collapse of the accretion disc in AGN confirmed by UV photometry and broad line spectra"
**Citation**: MNRAS 538, 121 (2024)
**Impact**: First direct observational confirmation of disk instability theory using UV photometry
**Key Results**: Disk collapse at η ~ 0.01; blue continuum drops by factor 2-5
**Link**: https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article/538/1/121/8045605

### 3. Near-Infrared AGN Diagnostics
**Title**: "Near-infrared emission line diagnostics for AGN from the local Universe to z ~ 3"
**Citation**: A&A 678, A147 (2023)

## Data and Survey References

### Multi-Wavelength Surveys
- **SDSS**: Sloan Digital Sky Survey - optical spectroscopy and photometry
- **XMM-Newton**: European Space Agency X-ray observatory - spectra and photometry
- **Chandra**: NASA X-ray observatory - imaging and grating spectroscopy
- **Swift**: NASA X-ray and UV observatory - rapid follow-up and monitoring
- **Spitzer**: NASA infrared observatory - mid-IR photometry and spectroscopy
- **WISE**: All-sky infrared survey - W1, W2, W3, W4 photometry
- **GALEX**: Galaxy Evolution Explorer - FUV and NUV all-sky survey
- **Fermi LAT**: Gamma-ray Large Area Telescope - gamma-ray observations
- **NuSTAR**: Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array - hard X-rays

### Radio Facilities
- **VLBA**: Very Long Baseline Array - sub-arcsecond radio imaging
- **EVN**: European VLBI Network - combined European telescopes
- **VLA**: Very Large Array - multi-frequency radio observations

## Emerging Frontiers (2025+)

### Near-Term (Next 1-2 Years)
1. JWST rest-frame optical spectroscopy of high-z (z ~ 2-3) AGN
2. Continued broad iron line reverberation spin measurements
3. High-resolution X-ray grating observations (XMM-Newton, Chandra)
4. Multi-wavelength variability monitoring campaigns
5. Mm-wavelength VLBI (Event Horizon Telescope precursors)

### Medium-Term (2-5 Years)
1. AXIS mission (Advanced X-ray Imaging Satellite) - improved high-resolution spectroscopy
2. AMXT (All-sky Monitors X-ray Transient) - continuous monitoring
3. Infrared interferometry (VLTI) - torus structure imaging
4. Large AGN samples with uniform multi-wavelength coverage

### Long-Term (5+ Years)
1. Next-generation X-ray missions with improved sensitivity
2. High-precision black hole spin measurements across AGN population
3. Tests of General Relativity in strong-field regime
4. AGN feedback mechanisms and galaxy evolution coupling
5. Multi-messenger observations (gravitational waves, neutrinos, EM)

# AGN Multi-Wavelength Radiation: Complete Literature Review Package

## Package Contents and Usage Guide

This directory contains a comprehensive literature review on multi-wavelength radiation characteristics of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), compiled from 120+ peer-reviewed papers, preprints, and technical reports spanning 2000-2025, with emphasis on recent advances (2020-2025).

## Research Coverage Summary

### Wavelength Coverage
- **Radio**: Sub-parsec to kiloparsec jets; VLBI observations; synchrotron radiation
- **Infrared**: Dusty torus; dust composition; WISE selection criteria; reverberation mapping
- **Optical**: Broad-line region; narrow-line region; BPT diagnostics; WHAN diagram; Seyfert classification
- **UV**: Accretion disk signature; disk instability; reverberation mapping; GALEX observations
- **X-Ray**: Hot corona; warm corona; soft X-ray excess; reflection spectroscopy; black hole spin measurement
- **Gamma-Ray**: Jets; blazars; inverse-Compton emission; TeV-emitting BL Lacs

**Total Electromagnetic Spectrum Covered**: ~8+ orders of magnitude (10⁹ Hz radio to 10²⁸ Hz gamma-ray)

### AGN Types Covered
- Type 1 (Seyfert 1, unobscured)
- Type 2 (Seyfert 2, obscured)
- Narrow-Line Seyfert 1 (NLSy1)
- Broad-Line Seyfert 1 (BLSy1)
- Quasars (radio-loud and radio-quiet)
- BL Lac objects (LBL, IBL, HBL)
- Flat-Spectrum Radio Quasars (FSRQ)
- Low-Ionization Nuclear Emission-line Regions (LINERs)
- Radio galaxies (FR I and FR II)

### Physics Components Covered
- **Accretion Physics**: Disk structure, two-temperature corona, warm corona, disk instability
- **Coronal Heating**: Magnetic reconnection, turbulent heating, particle acceleration
- **Black Hole Physics**: Spin measurement, relativistic effects, strong-field gravity tests
- **Photoionization**: BLR and NLR emission, line diagnostics, ionization mechanisms
- **Jets and Outflows**: Formation and collimation, relativistic outflows, accretion feedback
- **Dust Physics**: Torus composition, dust grain properties, infrared re-emission

## Quantitative Benchmarks Referenced

### AGN Demographics
- AGN fraction in galaxies: 1-10% (z ~ 0-2)
- Radio-loud AGN fraction: ~10%
- LINER prevalence: ~1/3 of nearby galaxies
- Type 1 vs. Type 2 ratio: 15-20% Type 1, 80-85% Type 2

### Black Hole Mass and Properties
- Black hole mass range: 10⁶-10¹⁰ M_sun
- Eddington ratio range: 0.01 to > 1.0
- Black hole spin measurements: ~40 AGN (a* from 0 to ~0.998)
- Spin population biased toward high spin (tentative)

### Accretion Disk and Corona
- UV peak: λ ~ 1000-10,000 Å
- Hot corona temperature: ~100-1000 keV
- Warm corona (when present): T ~ 0.1-1 keV, τ ~ 10-40
- Warm corona power contribution: ~50% of accretion luminosity
- X-ray spectral index: Γ ~ 1.7-2.5
- Soft X-ray excess frequency: ~50% of nearby AGN

### Emission Lines and Regions
- BLR size: 10-100 light-days (Seyfert 1)
- BLR electron density: 10⁸-10⁹ cm⁻³
- BLR velocity: FWHM 3,000-10,000 km/s
- NLR size: 100-1000+ pc
- NLR electron density: 10³-10⁶ cm⁻³
- NLR velocity: FWHM 300-1,000 km/s

### X-Ray Diagnostics
- Warm absorber incidence: 30-50% Type 1 AGN
- Absorber column density: 10²¹-10²³ cm⁻²
- Outflow velocity: 100-10,000 km/s
- Iron Kα line FWHM: 10,000-50,000 km/s (broad component)

### Infrared Properties
- Torus dust temperature (inner): 200-1500 K
- Torus dust temperature (outer): 50-100 K
- IR peak wavelength: 10-40 μm
- Type 2 IR luminosity: ~50% bolometric
- Type 1 IR luminosity: ~10% bolometric

### Radio Properties
- Radio-loud AGN jet Lorentz factor: Γ ~ 5-20
- Radio core spectral index: α ~ 0.1-0.3 (flat)
- Radio lobe spectral index: α ~ 0.7-1.0 (steep)
- Radio jet power: 10⁴³-10⁴⁶ erg/s

### Diagnostic Tool Performance
- WISE AGN selection: 61.9 per deg², 95% reliability, 78% completeness
- BPT diagram AGN identification: [OIII]/Hβ > 3
- NIR AGN detection improvement: ~60% more than optical

# Theoretical Framework: AGN vs. Star-Forming Galaxy Classification Using Multi-Wavelength Radiation

## 1. Problem Statement

### 1.1 Formal Definition

Let G represent a galaxy observed across multiple electromagnetic wavelength regimes. The classification problem is to determine the membership function:

```
C: G -> {AGN, SF, Composite, LINER, Ambiguous}
```

where:
- AGN = Active Galactic Nucleus dominated
- SF = Star Formation dominated
- Composite = Mixed AGN + SF contribution
- LINER = Low-Ionization Nuclear Emission-line Region
- Ambiguous = Insufficient information for classification

### 1.2 Mathematical Formulation

Given an observation vector **O** for galaxy G:

```
O = (O_opt, O_xray, O_mir, O_radio, O_sed)
```

where each component represents observations in a specific wavelength regime, we seek to find:

```
C*(G) = argmax_{c in Classes} P(c | O, M)
```

where M represents the physical model connecting observations to underlying physical processes.

---

## 2. State Variables and Observables

### 2.1 Optical Spectroscopic Variables

#### 2.1.1 Emission Line Fluxes
```
F = {F_[OIII]5007, F_Hbeta, F_[NII]6583, F_Halpha, F_[SII]6717,6731, F_[OI]6300}
```

#### 2.1.2 BPT Diagnostic Ratios
```
R1 = log10(F_[NII]6583 / F_Halpha)        # [NII]-BPT x-axis
R2 = log10(F_[OIII]5007 / F_Hbeta)        # [NII]-BPT y-axis
R3 = log10(F_[SII]6717+6731 / F_Halpha)   # [SII]-BPT x-axis
R4 = log10(F_[OI]6300 / F_Halpha)         # [OI]-BPT x-axis
```

#### 2.1.3 BPT Demarcation Lines

**Kewley et al. (2001) Maximum Starburst Line:**
```
log([OIII]/Hbeta) = 0.61 / (log([NII]/Halpha) - 0.47) + 1.19
```

**Kauffmann et al. (2003) Pure Star-Formation Line:**
```
log([OIII]/Hbeta) = 0.61 / (log([NII]/Halpha) - 0.05) + 1.30
```

### 2.2 X-ray Variables

#### 2.2.1 X-ray Luminosity
```
L_X = 4 * pi * D_L^2 * f_X * K(z, Gamma)
```
where:
- D_L = luminosity distance
- f_X = observed X-ray flux
- K(z, Gamma) = K-correction dependent on redshift z and photon index Gamma

#### 2.2.2 Hardness Ratios
```
HR1 = (H - S) / (H + S)
HR2 = (M - S) / (M + S)
```
where:
- S = soft band counts (0.5-2 keV)
- M = medium band counts (2-4.5 keV)
- H = hard band counts (4.5-10 keV)

#### 2.2.3 X-ray to Optical Ratio
```
alpha_OX = -0.384 * log10(L_2keV / L_2500A)
```

### 2.3 Mid-Infrared Variables

#### 2.3.1 WISE Color Indices
```
W1 = 3.4 micron magnitude
W2 = 4.6 micron magnitude
W3 = 12 micron magnitude
W4 = 22 micron magnitude

C_12 = W1 - W2  # Primary AGN indicator
C_23 = W2 - W3  # Dust temperature indicator
C_34 = W3 - W4  # Far-IR slope
```

#### 2.3.2 Stern et al. (2012) AGN Selection Criterion
```
AGN if: W1 - W2 >= 0.8
```

#### 2.3.3 Jarrett et al. (2011) Extended Criteria
```
AGN if: (W1 - W2 > 0.5) AND (W2 - W3 > 2.0)
```

### 2.4 Radio Variables

#### 2.4.1 Radio Luminosity
```
L_1.4GHz = 4 * pi * D_L^2 * S_1.4GHz * (1+z)^(alpha-1)
```
where alpha is the spectral index (S_nu proportional to nu^alpha)

#### 2.4.2 Radio Loudness Parameter
```
R = L_5GHz / L_B = f_5GHz / f_4400A
```
Classification:
- Radio-quiet: R < 10
- Radio-loud: R >= 10

#### 2.4.3 FIR-Radio Correlation Parameter
```
q_IR = log10(S_FIR / (3.75 * 10^12 Hz)) - log10(S_1.4GHz)
```
where S_FIR is the far-infrared flux density.

Star-forming galaxies: q_IR ~ 2.34 +/- 0.26
AGN excess: q_IR < 1.8

#### 2.4.4 Radio Morphological Index
```
M_radio in {Compact, Extended_jets, Extended_lobes, Diffuse}
```

### 2.5 SED-Derived Variables

#### 2.5.1 Spectral Energy Distribution
```
SED(nu) = L_nu(nu) = {L_nu,i} for i in wavelength bins
```

#### 2.5.2 AGN Fraction
```
f_AGN = L_AGN / (L_AGN + L_host)
```
typically measured at rest-frame 6 micron or via decomposition.

---

## 3. Physical Assumptions and Governing Equations

### 3.1 Star Formation Signatures

**Assumption SF1:** Star formation produces thermal emission from HII regions with characteristic ionization conditions.

The ionization parameter for HII regions:
```
U_SF = Q(H0) / (4 * pi * r^2 * n_H * c) ~ 10^(-3.5) to 10^(-2.5)
```

**Assumption SF2:** The hardness of the ionizing radiation field is limited by stellar temperatures:
```
T_eff <= 50,000 K  =>  E_peak < 4 * k * T_eff ~ 17 eV
```

**Assumption SF3:** Star formation follows the FIR-radio correlation:
```
L_FIR / L_1.4GHz = constant (within scatter)
```
Physical basis: Both FIR and radio trace massive star formation (dust heating and supernova remnants).

### 3.2 AGN Signatures

**Assumption AGN1:** AGN produce hard ionizing continuum from accretion disk:
```
L_nu proportional to nu^(-alpha_UV)  for UV/optical
L_nu proportional to nu^(-Gamma+1)   for X-ray (Gamma ~ 1.8-2.0)
```

**Assumption AGN2:** The dusty torus reprocesses UV/optical emission:
```
L_MIR ~ 0.1-0.5 * L_bol,AGN
```
Produces characteristic red MIR colors (W1-W2 > 0.8).

**Assumption AGN3:** AGN X-ray emission originates from inverse Compton scattering in the corona:
```
L_X(2-10 keV) / L_bol ~ 0.03-0.1 (for unobscured AGN)
```

**Assumption AGN4:** Radio jets in AGN are decoupled from star formation:
```
L_radio(AGN) >> L_radio(SF) at matched SFR
```

### 3.3 Composite Systems

**Assumption COMP1:** In composite systems, observables are linear combinations:
```
O_total = f_AGN * O_AGN + (1 - f_AGN) * O_SF + epsilon
```
where epsilon represents interaction terms and non-linear effects.

---

## 4. Multi-Dimensional Classification Hypothesis

### 4.1 Primary Hypothesis (H1)

**Statement:** A multi-wavelength classification scheme incorporating optical emission line ratios, X-ray properties, MIR colors, radio characteristics, and SED decomposition will achieve classification accuracy >= 95% with contamination rate <= 5%, outperforming any single-wavelength diagnostic by at least 15% in purity.

**Formalization:**
```
Let A_multi = accuracy using multi-wavelength features
Let A_single,i = accuracy using only wavelength regime i

H1: A_multi >= 0.95 AND A_multi - max(A_single,i) >= 0.15
```

### 4.2 Secondary Hypothesis (H2)

**Statement:** The classification boundary in the joint feature space is non-linear, and machine learning classifiers (Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, or Neural Networks) will outperform linear discriminant analysis by at least 10% in F1-score.

**Formalization:**
```
Let F1_ML = F1-score for best ML classifier
Let F1_LDA = F1-score for linear discriminant analysis

H2: F1_ML - F1_LDA >= 0.10
```

### 4.3 Tertiary Hypothesis (H3)

**Statement:** Feature importance analysis will reveal that the relative importance of diagnostic wavelength regimes varies with redshift, with X-ray and MIR becoming increasingly important at z > 1 where optical spectroscopy becomes challenging.

**Formalization:**
```
Let I_i(z) = importance of feature set i at redshift z

H3: d(I_xray)/dz > 0 AND d(I_mir)/dz > 0 for z in [0.5, 3.0]
```

### 4.4 Falsification Criteria

- **H1 falsified if:** A_multi < 0.90 OR improvement over single-wavelength < 0.05
- **H2 falsified if:** F1_ML - F1_LDA < 0.05 (i.e., linear methods perform comparably)
- **H3 falsified if:** Feature importance is redshift-independent within statistical uncertainty

---

## 5. Feature Vector Definition

### 5.1 Complete Feature Vector

For each galaxy G, construct the feature vector:

```
X = [
    # Optical (4 features)
    R1,                          # log([NII]/Halpha)
    R2,                          # log([OIII]/Hbeta)
    R3,                          # log([SII]/Halpha)
    R4,                          # log([OI]/Halpha)

    # X-ray (4 features)
    log10(L_X),                  # X-ray luminosity
    HR1,                         # Hard/Soft hardness ratio
    alpha_OX,                    # X-ray to optical slope
    Gamma,                       # Photon index (if available)

    # MIR (4 features)
    C_12,                        # W1 - W2
    C_23,                        # W2 - W3
    C_34,                        # W3 - W4
    log10(L_6um),                # 6 micron luminosity

    # Radio (4 features)
    log10(L_1.4GHz),             # Radio luminosity
    log10(R),                    # Radio loudness
    q_IR,                        # FIR-radio parameter
    M_radio_encoded,             # Morphology (one-hot or ordinal)

    # SED (3 features)
    f_AGN,                       # AGN fraction from decomposition
    log10(M_star),               # Stellar mass
    log10(SFR),                  # Star formation rate

    # Ancillary (2 features)
    z,                           # Redshift
    log10(M_BH)                  # Black hole mass (if available)
]
```

Total: 21 primary features (+ additional morphology encoding)

### 5.2 Missing Data Handling

Define missingness indicator matrix:
```
M_ij = 1 if feature j is observed for galaxy i, 0 otherwise
```

Strategies:
1. Complete case analysis (strict)
2. Imputation via multivariate methods
3. Model-based handling (e.g., XGBoost native support)

---

## 6. Classification Model Architecture

### 6.1 Hierarchical Classification Scheme

```
Level 1: Binary classification
    - Active (AGN-like) vs. Inactive (SF-dominated)

Level 2: For Active sources
    - Type 1 AGN (unobscured)
    - Type 2 AGN (obscured)
    - LINER

Level 3: For any class
    - Composite flag (f_AGN in [0.2, 0.8])
```

### 6.2 Ensemble Classifier Structure

```
Classifier_final = weighted_vote(
    C_RF,          # Random Forest
    C_XGB,         # XGBoost
    C_NN,          # Neural Network
    C_BPT,         # Traditional BPT rules
    C_MIR,         # MIR color cuts
    C_Xray         # X-ray diagnostic rules
)
```

Weights determined via cross-validation optimization.

---

## 7. Experimental Pseudocode

### 7.1 Data Preparation Phase

```
ALGORITHM: Data_Preparation
INPUT: Raw multi-wavelength catalog files
OUTPUT: Cleaned feature matrix X, label vector Y

1. LOAD optical spectroscopy catalog (e.g., SDSS DR17)
   - Extract: RA, Dec, z, emission line fluxes, line errors
   - Filter: S/N >= 3 for all BPT lines

2. LOAD X-ray catalog (e.g., Chandra Source Catalog, XMM-Newton)
   - Extract: X-ray fluxes in soft/medium/hard bands
   - Compute: L_X using spectroscopic redshift

3. LOAD MIR catalog (e.g., WISE AllWISE)
   - Extract: W1, W2, W3, W4 magnitudes and errors
   - Filter: S/N >= 5 in W1 and W2

4. LOAD radio catalog (e.g., FIRST, VLASS, LOFAR)
   - Extract: Integrated flux density, morphological classification
   - Compute: L_1.4GHz, radio loudness R

5. LOAD SED-derived parameters (e.g., CIGALE, MAGPHYS outputs)
   - Extract: M_star, SFR, f_AGN

6. CROSS-MATCH catalogs using positional matching
   - Primary match radius: 2 arcsec (optical to X-ray, MIR)
   - Secondary match radius: 5 arcsec (radio, accounting for jet offsets)
   - Resolve duplicates via likelihood ratio

7. COMPUTE derived features
   FOR each galaxy G in matched catalog:
       R1 = log10(F_[NII] / F_Halpha)
       R2 = log10(F_[OIII] / F_Hbeta)
       R3 = log10(F_[SII] / F_Halpha)
       R4 = log10(F_[OI] / F_Halpha)
       HR1 = (H - S) / (H + S)
       alpha_OX = -0.384 * log10(L_2keV / L_2500A)
       C_12 = W1 - W2
       C_23 = W2 - W3
       q_IR = compute_qIR(S_FIR, S_1.4GHz)
   END FOR

8. ASSIGN ground truth labels Y
   - Use expert-classified training set OR
   - Consensus from multiple diagnostic methods
   - Label categories: {0: SF, 1: AGN, 2: Composite, 3: LINER, 4: Ambiguous}

9. HANDLE missing values
   - Create missingness matrix M
   - Option A: Remove galaxies with > 50% missing features
   - Option B: Impute using IterativeImputer (MICE algorithm)

10. NORMALIZE features
    - Standardization: X_norm = (X - mu) / sigma
    - Store mu, sigma for test data transformation

11. OUTPUT: X_train, X_test, Y_train, Y_test (80/20 split, stratified)
```

### 7.2 Traditional Diagnostic Implementation

```
ALGORITHM: Traditional_Diagnostics
INPUT: Feature matrix X
OUTPUT: Predictions Y_trad for each diagnostic method

1. BPT CLASSIFICATION
   FOR each galaxy G:
       # [NII]-BPT diagram
       IF R2 < 0.61/(R1 - 0.05) + 1.30:
           BPT_class = "SF"
       ELSE IF R2 < 0.61/(R1 - 0.47) + 1.19:
           BPT_class = "Composite"
       ELSE IF R1 < 0.0:
           BPT_class = "Seyfert"
       ELSE:
           BPT_class = "LINER"
       END IF
   END FOR

2. X-RAY CLASSIFICATION
   FOR each galaxy G:
       IF L_X > 10^42 erg/s:
           Xray_class = "AGN"
       ELSE IF HR1 > -0.2 AND L_X > 10^41:
           Xray_class = "Obscured_AGN_candidate"
       ELSE:
           Xray_class = "SF_or_weak_AGN"
       END IF
   END FOR

3. MIR CLASSIFICATION
   FOR each galaxy G:
       IF C_12 >= 0.8:
           MIR_class = "AGN" (Stern criterion)
       ELSE IF C_12 > 0.5 AND C_23 > 2.0:
           MIR_class = "AGN" (Jarrett criterion)
       ELSE:
           MIR_class = "SF_or_weak_AGN"
       END IF
   END FOR

4. RADIO CLASSIFICATION
   FOR each galaxy G:
       IF R >= 10:
           Radio_class = "Radio-loud_AGN"
       ELSE IF q_IR < 1.8:
           Radio_class = "Radio-excess_AGN"
       ELSE:
           Radio_class = "SF_consistent"
       END IF
   END FOR

5. CONSENSUS VOTING
   FOR each galaxy G:
       votes = [BPT_class, Xray_class, MIR_class, Radio_class]
       Y_trad[G] = majority_vote(votes)
       confidence[G] = agreement_fraction(votes)
   END FOR

6. OUTPUT: Y_trad, confidence scores, individual diagnostic results
```

### 7.3 Machine Learning Classification

```
ALGORITHM: ML_Classification
INPUT: X_train, Y_train, X_test, Y_test
OUTPUT: Trained models, predictions, performance metrics

1. DEFINE model architectures

   # Random Forest
   RF_params = {
       n_estimators: 500,
       max_depth: 20,
       min_samples_split: 5,
       min_samples_leaf: 2,
       class_weight: "balanced"
   }

   # XGBoost
   XGB_params = {
       n_estimators: 500,
       max_depth: 8,
       learning_rate: 0.05,
       subsample: 0.8,
       colsample_bytree: 0.8,
       scale_pos_weight: computed_from_class_distribution
   }

   # Neural Network
   NN_architecture = {
       input_dim: 21,
       hidden_layers: [128, 64, 32],
       activation: "ReLU",
       output_dim: 5,
       output_activation: "Softmax",
       dropout_rate: 0.3,
       batch_norm: True
   }

2. CROSS-VALIDATION setup
   cv_folds = 5
   cv_strategy = StratifiedKFold(n_splits=cv_folds, shuffle=True)

3. TRAIN Random Forest
   FOR each fold in cv_strategy:
       RF_model.fit(X_train_fold, Y_train_fold)
       Y_pred_fold = RF_model.predict(X_val_fold)
       store_metrics(Y_val_fold, Y_pred_fold)
   END FOR
   RF_final.fit(X_train, Y_train)

4. TRAIN XGBoost
   FOR each fold in cv_strategy:
       XGB_model.fit(X_train_fold, Y_train_fold,
                     eval_set=(X_val_fold, Y_val_fold),
                     early_stopping_rounds=50)
       Y_pred_fold = XGB_model.predict(X_val_fold)
       store_metrics(Y_val_fold, Y_pred_fold)
   END FOR
   XGB_final.fit(X_train, Y_train)

5. TRAIN Neural Network
   optimizer = Adam(lr=0.001)
   loss_function = CrossEntropyLoss(weights=class_weights)

   FOR epoch in range(200):
       FOR batch in DataLoader(X_train, Y_train, batch_size=256):
           loss = loss_function(NN_model(batch_X), batch_Y)
           loss.backward()
           optimizer.step()
       END FOR
       IF early_stopping_criterion_met:
           BREAK
   END FOR

6. HYPERPARAMETER TUNING (optional)
   Use Bayesian optimization or RandomizedSearchCV
   Optimize: F1-macro score

7. ENSEMBLE CONSTRUCTION
   FOR each galaxy in X_test:
       P_RF = RF_final.predict_proba(X)
       P_XGB = XGB_final.predict_proba(X)
       P_NN = NN_final.predict_proba(X)

       # Weighted average (weights from CV performance)
       P_ensemble = w_RF*P_RF + w_XGB*P_XGB + w_NN*P_NN
       Y_ensemble = argmax(P_ensemble)
   END FOR

8. OUTPUT: Trained models, Y_pred_ensemble, probability matrices
```

### 7.4 Evaluation and Validation

```
ALGORITHM: Evaluation
INPUT: Y_test, Y_pred (from traditional and ML methods)
OUTPUT: Performance metrics, comparison tables, visualizations

1. COMPUTE classification metrics
   FOR each method M in {Traditional, RF, XGB, NN, Ensemble}:

       # Per-class metrics
       FOR each class C in {SF, AGN, Composite, LINER, Ambiguous}:
           precision[M][C] = TP / (TP + FP)
           recall[M][C] = TP / (TP + FN)
           F1[M][C] = 2 * precision * recall / (precision + recall)
       END FOR

       # Aggregate metrics
       accuracy[M] = sum(correct) / total
       F1_macro[M] = mean(F1 per class)
       F1_weighted[M] = weighted_mean(F1, class_sizes)

       # Confusion matrix
       CM[M] = confusion_matrix(Y_test, Y_pred[M])

       # ROC-AUC (one-vs-rest)
       AUC[M] = roc_auc_score(Y_test, Y_prob[M], multi_class='ovr')

   END FOR

2. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE TESTING
   # McNemar's test for paired classifier comparison
   FOR each pair (M1, M2):
       contingency_table = compute_mcnemar_table(Y_pred[M1], Y_pred[M2], Y_test)
       p_value = mcnemar_test(contingency_table)
       significant[M1, M2] = (p_value < 0.05)
   END FOR

3. FEATURE IMPORTANCE ANALYSIS
   # Random Forest importance
   RF_importance = RF_final.feature_importances_

   # Permutation importance (model-agnostic)
   FOR each feature f:
       baseline_score = evaluate(model, X_test, Y_test)
       X_test_permuted = permute_column(X_test, f)
       permuted_score = evaluate(model, X_test_permuted, Y_test)
       importance[f] = baseline_score - permuted_score
   END FOR

   # SHAP values for interpretability
   shap_values = shap.TreeExplainer(XGB_final).shap_values(X_test)

4. REDSHIFT-DEPENDENT ANALYSIS
   z_bins = [0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 3.0]
   FOR each z_bin:
       subset = X_test[z in z_bin]
       metrics_z[z_bin] = compute_metrics(Y_test[subset], Y_pred[subset])
       importance_z[z_bin] = compute_importance(model, subset)
   END FOR

5. CALIBRATION ANALYSIS
   # Reliability diagram
   FOR each probability bin b in [0, 0.1, ..., 0.9, 1.0]:
       fraction_positive[b] = mean(Y_test[P in b])
       mean_predicted_prob[b] = mean(P[P in b])
   END FOR

   # Expected Calibration Error
   ECE = sum(|fraction_positive - mean_predicted_prob| * bin_weight)

6. VALIDATION ON INDEPENDENT DATASET
   # Load external validation set (different survey/selection)
   X_val_external, Y_val_external = load_validation_data()
   Y_pred_external = ensemble_model.predict(X_val_external)
   external_metrics = compute_metrics(Y_val_external, Y_pred_external)

7. OUTPUT: Performance summary table, confusion matrices,
           feature importance rankings, calibration plots,
           redshift-dependent performance curves
```

### 7.5 Uncertainty Quantification

```
ALGORITHM: Uncertainty_Quantification
INPUT: Trained models, X_test
OUTPUT: Prediction uncertainties, confidence intervals

1. ENSEMBLE DISAGREEMENT
   FOR each galaxy G:
       predictions = [RF.predict(G), XGB.predict(G), NN.predict(G)]
       ensemble_uncertainty[G] = entropy(vote_distribution(predictions))
   END FOR

2. BOOTSTRAP UNCERTAINTY
   n_bootstrap = 100
   FOR b in range(n_bootstrap):
       X_boot, Y_boot = resample(X_train, Y_train)
       model_boot = train_model(X_boot, Y_boot)
       Y_pred_boot[b] = model_boot.predict(X_test)
   END FOR

   FOR each galaxy G:
       bootstrap_CI[G] = percentile(Y_pred_boot[:, G], [2.5, 97.5])
       bootstrap_std[G] = std(Y_pred_boot[:, G])
   END FOR

3. MC DROPOUT (for Neural Network)
   n_forward = 50
   enable_dropout_at_inference()
   FOR i in range(n_forward):
       Y_pred_mc[i] = NN_model.predict(X_test)
   END FOR

   epistemic_uncertainty = std(Y_pred_mc, axis=0)
   predictive_entropy = -sum(P * log(P)) where P = mean(Y_pred_mc)

4. CONFORMAL PREDICTION
   # Calibration set split
   X_cal, Y_cal = X_train[-1000:], Y_train[-1000:]

   # Compute non-conformity scores
   scores = 1 - model.predict_proba(X_cal)[Y_cal]

   # Compute prediction sets at confidence level alpha
   alpha = 0.10
   threshold = quantile(scores, 1 - alpha)

   FOR each galaxy G in X_test:
       probs = model.predict_proba(G)
       prediction_set[G] = {c : probs[c] > 1 - threshold}
   END FOR

5. OUTPUT: Uncertainty estimates per galaxy, prediction intervals,
           prediction sets with coverage guarantees
```

## 8. Expected Performance Metrics

### 8.1 Baseline Expectations (Single-Wavelength)

| Method | Expected Accuracy | Expected F1-macro | Primary Limitation |
|--------|------------------|-------------------|-------------------|
| BPT only | 75-80% | 0.70-0.75 | Requires spectroscopy; fails at z > 0.4 |
| X-ray only | 70-75% | 0.65-0.70 | Misses obscured AGN; incompleteness |
| MIR only | 72-78% | 0.68-0.73 | Contamination from dusty SF; blending |
| Radio only | 60-70% | 0.55-0.65 | Majority radio-quiet; morphology needed |

### 8.2 Multi-Wavelength Expectations

| Method | Expected Accuracy | Expected F1-macro | Expected AUC |
|--------|------------------|-------------------|--------------|
| Traditional consensus | 82-87% | 0.78-0.83 | 0.88-0.92 |
| Random Forest | 88-92% | 0.84-0.88 | 0.93-0.96 |
| XGBoost | 89-93% | 0.85-0.89 | 0.94-0.97 |
| Neural Network | 87-91% | 0.83-0.87 | 0.92-0.95 |
| Ensemble | 91-95% | 0.87-0.91 | 0.95-0.98 |

### 8.3 Per-Class Expected Performance

| Class | Expected Precision | Expected Recall | Notes |
|-------|-------------------|-----------------|-------|
| SF | 0.92-0.96 | 0.94-0.97 | Largest class; well-defined signatures |
| AGN (Type 1) | 0.90-0.95 | 0.85-0.92 | Strong multi-wavelength signatures |
| AGN (Type 2) | 0.82-0.88 | 0.78-0.85 | Obscuration challenges |
| Composite | 0.70-0.80 | 0.65-0.75 | Inherently ambiguous; continuum problem |
| LINER | 0.75-0.85 | 0.70-0.80 | Overlap with other classes |

## 9. Validation Strategy

### 9.1 Internal Validation

1. **Stratified K-fold Cross-Validation** (k=5)
   - Ensures class balance in each fold
   - Provides robust performance estimates

2. **Temporal Split** (if time-domain data available)
   - Train on observations before cutoff date
   - Test on observations after cutoff date

3. **Spatial Split**
   - Train on one survey region
   - Test on non-overlapping region

### 9.2 External Validation

1. **Independent Survey Validation**
   - Train: SDSS + Chandra + WISE + FIRST
   - Test: GAMA + XMM-Newton + Spitzer + LOFAR

2. **Spectroscopic Verification**
   - For high-confidence predictions, compare against deep spectroscopy
   - Expected agreement: > 90%

3. **Expert Panel Review**
   - Random sample of 500 ambiguous cases
   - Independent classification by 3+ experts
   - Compute inter-rater reliability (Fleiss' kappa)

### 9.3 Robustness Tests

1. **Noise Injection**
   - Add Gaussian noise at levels sigma, 2*sigma, 3*sigma
   - Track performance degradation

2. **Feature Ablation**
   - Systematically remove wavelength regimes
   - Quantify contribution of each regime

3. **Selection Bias Assessment**
   - Compare performance across different magnitude/flux limits
   - Evaluate completeness vs. redshift

---

## 10. Outputs and Deliverables

### 10.1 Data Products

1. **Classified Catalog**
   - Galaxy ID, coordinates, redshift
   - Classification (5 classes)
   - Probability vector P(class)
   - Uncertainty estimate
   - Feature values used

2. **Model Artifacts**
   - Trained model weights/parameters
   - Normalization parameters (mu, sigma)
   - Feature importance rankings

### 10.2 Diagnostic Outputs

1. **Confusion Matrices** (per method and overall)
2. **ROC Curves** (per class, one-vs-rest)
3. **Precision-Recall Curves**
4. **Calibration Plots** (reliability diagrams)
5. **SHAP Summary Plots** (feature importance)
6. **Redshift-dependent Performance Curves**

### 10.3 Scientific Outputs

1. **Contamination Rate Analysis**
   - False AGN rate in SF sample
   - False SF rate in AGN sample

2. **Completeness Analysis**
   - Recovery fraction by class
   - Dependence on luminosity, redshift

3. **Comparison with Literature Classifications**
   - Agreement rate with published AGN catalogs
   - Identification of discrepant sources

---

## 11. Limitations and Caveats

### 11.1 Known Limitations

1. **Redshift Dependence**: Optical diagnostics fail at z > 0.4-0.5 due to emission line shifts.

2. **Selection Effects**: Multi-wavelength matching biases toward bright, detected sources.

3. **Composite Nature**: The SF/AGN boundary is a continuum, not discrete.

4. **Variability**: AGN are variable; single-epoch observations may misclassify.

5. **Obscuration**: Heavily obscured AGN may evade all diagnostics except hard X-ray/MIR.

### 11.2 Scope Constraints

- Framework assumes sufficient spectroscopic coverage
- Radio morphology requires arcsecond-resolution imaging
- SED decomposition requires photometry in >= 10 bands

---

## 12. Summary

This theoretical framework provides a rigorous foundation for multi-wavelength AGN vs. star-forming galaxy classification. The key innovations are:

1. **Unified Feature Space**: Integration of 21 features across 5 wavelength regimes into a single classification framework.

2. **Hierarchical Classification**: Two-level scheme separating active/inactive and then subclassifying.

3. **Ensemble Approach**: Combination of traditional astrophysical diagnostics with modern ML methods.

4. **Uncertainty Quantification**: Multiple methods (ensemble disagreement, bootstrap, MC dropout, conformal prediction) for robust uncertainty estimates.

5. **Comprehensive Validation**: Internal cross-validation, external survey validation, and expert review.

The experimentalist should implement this framework following the pseudocode algorithms sequentially, beginning with data preparation and proceeding through classification and evaluation phases.

# Quick Reference: Equations and Parameters for AGN/SF Classification

## 1. Core Diagnostic Equations

### 1.1 BPT Diagram Ratios

```
R1 = log10(F_[NII]6583 / F_Halpha)
R2 = log10(F_[OIII]5007 / F_Hbeta)
R3 = log10(F_[SII]6717+6731 / F_Halpha)
R4 = log10(F_[OI]6300 / F_Halpha)
```

### 1.2 BPT Demarcation Lines

**Kauffmann+03 (SF boundary):**
```
log([OIII]/Hbeta) = 0.61 / (log([NII]/Halpha) - 0.05) + 1.30
```

**Kewley+01 (extreme starburst line):**
```
log([OIII]/Hbeta) = 0.61 / (log([NII]/Halpha) - 0.47) + 1.19
```

**Seyfert/LINER divider (Schawinski+07):**
```
log([OIII]/Hbeta) = 1.05 * log([NII]/Halpha) + 0.45
```

### 1.3 X-ray Diagnostics

**X-ray Luminosity:**
```
L_X = 4 * pi * D_L^2 * f_X * K(z, Gamma)
```

**Hardness Ratio:**
```
HR = (H - S) / (H + S)

where:
  S = 0.5-2 keV counts
  H = 2-10 keV counts
```

**X-ray to Optical Slope:**
```
alpha_OX = -0.384 * log10(L_2keV / L_2500A)
         = 0.384 * log10(L_2500A / L_2keV)
```

**AGN Threshold:**
```
L_X(2-10 keV) > 10^42 erg/s  =>  AGN
```

### 1.4 Mid-Infrared Diagnostics

**WISE Colors:**
```
W1 - W2 >= 0.8         (Stern+12 AGN criterion)
W1 - W2 > 0.5 AND W2 - W3 > 2.0   (Jarrett+11)
```

**Vega to AB Conversion:**
```
W1_AB = W1_Vega + 2.699
W2_AB = W2_Vega + 3.339
W3_AB = W3_Vega + 5.174
W4_AB = W4_Vega + 6.620
```

### 1.5 Radio Diagnostics

**Radio Luminosity:**
```
L_1.4GHz = 4 * pi * D_L^2 * S_1.4GHz * (1+z)^(alpha-1)

where alpha ~ -0.7 (typical synchrotron spectral index)
```

**Radio Loudness:**
```
R = f_5GHz / f_4400A  (or L_5GHz / L_B)

R < 10   =>  Radio-quiet
R >= 10  =>  Radio-loud
```

**FIR-Radio Correlation:**
```
q_IR = log10(S_FIR / (3.75 * 10^12 Hz)) - log10(S_1.4GHz)

SF galaxies: q_IR = 2.34 +/- 0.26
AGN excess:  q_IR < 1.8
```

---

## 2. Key Physical Constants and Thresholds

| Parameter | Threshold | Classification |
|-----------|-----------|----------------|
| L_X (2-10 keV) | > 10^42 erg/s | AGN |
| L_X (2-10 keV) | > 10^44 erg/s | Luminous AGN / QSO |
| W1 - W2 | >= 0.8 | AGN (Stern criterion) |
| R (radio loudness) | >= 10 | Radio-loud AGN |
| q_IR | < 1.8 | Radio-excess AGN |
| Eddington ratio | > 0.01 | Active AGN |

---

## 3. Feature Vector Specification

### 3.1 Complete Feature List (21 features)

```python
feature_names = [
    # Optical (indices 0-3)
    'log_NII_Ha',           # R1
    'log_OIII_Hb',          # R2
    'log_SII_Ha',           # R3
    'log_OI_Ha',            # R4

    # X-ray (indices 4-7)
    'log_L_X',              # log10(L_X in erg/s)
    'HR1',                  # Hardness ratio
    'alpha_OX',             # X-ray to optical slope
    'Gamma',                # Photon index

    # MIR (indices 8-11)
    'W1_W2',                # W1 - W2 color
    'W2_W3',                # W2 - W3 color
    'W3_W4',                # W3 - W4 color
    'log_L_6um',            # log10(L_6um in erg/s)

    # Radio (indices 12-15)
    'log_L_1p4GHz',         # log10(L_1.4GHz in W/Hz)
    'log_R',                # log10(radio loudness)
    'q_IR',                 # FIR-radio parameter
    'morph_radio',          # Morphology code (0-3)

    # SED (indices 16-18)
    'f_AGN',                # AGN fraction [0,1]
    'log_Mstar',            # log10(M_star in M_sun)
    'log_SFR',# log10(SFR in M_sun/yr)

    # Ancillary (indices 19-20)
    'z',                    # Spectroscopic redshift
    'log_MBH'               # log10(M_BH in M_sun)
]
```

### 3.2 Class Labels

```python
class_labels = {
    0: 'SF',           # Star-forming
    1: 'AGN',          # Active Galactic Nucleus
    2: 'Composite',    # Mixed SF + AGN
    3: 'LINER',        # Low-Ionization Nuclear Emission Region
    4: 'Ambiguous'     # Insufficient information
}
```

---

## 4. Model Hyperparameters (Recommended Starting Points)

### 4.1 Random Forest

```python
rf_params = {
    'n_estimators': 500,
    'max_depth': 20,
    'min_samples_split': 5,
    'min_samples_leaf': 2,
    'max_features': 'sqrt',
    'class_weight': 'balanced',
    'random_state': 42,
    'n_jobs': -1
}
```

### 4.2 XGBoost

```python
xgb_params = {
    'n_estimators': 500,
    'max_depth': 8,
    'learning_rate': 0.05,
    'subsample': 0.8,
    'colsample_bytree': 0.8,
    'reg_alpha': 0.1,
    'reg_lambda': 1.0,
    'objective': 'multi:softprob',
    'num_class': 5,
    'eval_metric': 'mlogloss',
    'use_label_encoder': False,
    'random_state': 42
}
```

### 4.3 Neural Network

```python
nn_config = {
    'input_dim': 21,
    'hidden_layers': [128, 64, 32],
    'activation': 'ReLU',
    'output_dim': 5,
    'dropout_rate': 0.3,
    'batch_norm': True,
    'learning_rate': 0.001,
    'batch_size': 256,
    'max_epochs': 200,
    'early_stopping_patience': 20
}
```

---

## 5. Evaluation Metrics Formulas

### 5.1 Classification Metrics

```
Precision = TP / (TP + FP)
Recall = TP / (TP + FN)
F1 = 2 * Precision * Recall / (Precision + Recall)

Accuracy = (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN)

F1_macro = (1/n_classes) * sum(F1_c for c in classes)
F1_weighted = sum(n_c * F1_c) / sum(n_c)
```

### 5.2 Calibration Metrics

```
Expected Calibration Error (ECE):
ECE = sum_{b=1}^{B} (n_b / N) * |accuracy_b - confidence_b|

Brier Score:
BS = (1/N) * sum_{i=1}^{N} (p_i - y_i)^2
```

---

## 6. Cross-Match Radii

| Match Type | Recommended Radius | Notes |
|------------|-------------------|-------|
| Optical to X-ray | 2.0 arcsec | Chandra positional accuracy |
| Optical to MIR | 2.0 arcsec | WISE beam ~6 arcsec, but centroid good |
| Optical to Radio | 1.5 arcsec (core) | For core-dominated sources |
| Optical to Radio | 5.0 arcsec (jets) | Allow for jet offsets |
| Likelihood ratio threshold | LR > 0.5 | Probability-based matching |

---

## 7. Data Quality Cuts

### 7.1 Optical Spectroscopy

```
S/N([OIII]5007) >= 3
S/N(Hbeta) >= 3
S/N([NII]6583) >= 3
S/N(Halpha) >= 3
EW(Halpha) > 3 Angstrom  # Ensure emission line galaxy
```

### 7.2 X-ray

```
Net counts > 10  (for spectral analysis)
Net counts > 5   (for detection)
Off-axis angle < 10 arcmin  (for Chandra)
```

### 7.3 MIR

```
S/N(W1) >= 5
S/N(W2) >= 5
cc_flags == '0000'  # No contamination/confusion
ext_flg == 0        # Point source
```

### 7.4 Radio

```
S/N(peak) >= 5
Integrated/Peak < 1.5 OR morphological analysis performed
```

---

## 8. Luminosity Distance Formula

```
D_L(z) = (c/H_0) * (1+z) * integral_0^z dz' / E(z')

where:
E(z) = sqrt(Omega_m * (1+z)^3 + Omega_Lambda)

For flat Lambda-CDM with:
H_0 = 70 km/s/Mpc
Omega_m = 0.3
Omega_Lambda = 0.7
```

---

## 9. K-Correction Approximations

### 9.1 X-ray K-correction

```
K_X(z, Gamma) = (1+z)^(Gamma - 2)

For Gamma = 1.8 (typical AGN):
K_X = (1+z)^(-0.2)
```

### 9.2 Radio K-correction

```
K_radio(z, alpha) = (1+z)^(alpha - 1)

For alpha = -0.7 (synchrotron):
K_radio = (1+z)^(-1.7)
```

---

## 10. Implementation Checklist

1. [ ] Load and cross-match catalogs
2. [ ] Compute all derived features (R1-R4, HR, alpha_OX, colors, q_IR)
3. [ ] Apply quality cuts
4. [ ] Handle missing data (imputation or exclusion)
5. [ ] Standardize features
6. [ ] Split train/test (80/20, stratified)
7. [ ] Train traditional classifiers (BPT, X-ray, MIR, radio)
8. [ ] Train ML classifiers (RF, XGB, NN)
9. [ ] Construct ensemble
10. [ ] Evaluate on test set
11. [ ] Compute uncertainty estimates
12. [ ] Validate on external dataset
13. [ ] Generate diagnostic plots
14. [ ] Save classified catalog

---

## 11. Expected Output Files

```
outputs/
  catalogs/
    classified_catalog.fits
    classified_catalog.csv
    probability_matrix.npy
  models/
    random_forest.pkl
    xgboost.json
    neural_network.pt
    scaler.pkl
  figures/
    confusion_matrix.png
    roc_curves.png
    feature_importance.png
    calibration_plot.png
    bpt_diagram_classified.png
    wise_color_classified.png
  metrics/
    performance_summary.csv
    cross_validation_results.csv
    external_validation_results.csv
```

# Data Sources for AGN vs. Star-Forming Galaxy Classification

This directory contains documentation of real-world multi-wavelength datasets suitable for AGN classification.

## Main Documentation File

`data_sources_agn_classification.md` - Comprehensive documentation of 25+ multi-wavelength datasets

## Quick Summary

### Top Recommended Datasets:

1. **SDSS DR16 Multi-wavelength Crossmatch** (~30,000 sources, UV+optical+X-ray+IR, 98% ML accuracy demonstrated)
2. **COSMOS2020 + X-ray/radio cross-matches** (1.7M sources, 30+ bands, tens of thousands labelable)
3. **eRASS1 AGN Catalog** (900,000+ X-ray sources with ML classifications)
4. **Chandra Deep Field South 7 Ms** (1,008 sources, 98.4% with multi-wavelength counterparts)
5. **MPA-JHU SDSS Catalog** (900,000 galaxies with BPT classifications)

### Data Access:
- NASA HEASARC: https://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/
- IRSA/IPAC: https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/
- SDSS: https://skyserver.sdss.org/
- eROSITA-DE: https://erosita.mpe.mpg.de/dr1/

### Conclusion:
**Real-world data is sufficient - no synthetic data generation required.**
Combined training set: 50,000-100,000+ labeled sources achievable.

Created: 2025-12-22

MULTI-WAVELENGTH DATASETS FOR AGN VS. STAR-FORMING GALAXY CLASSIFICATION
Document Created: 2025-12-22
Status: COMPLETE - Real datasets identified, NO synthetic data needed

================================================================================
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
================================================================================

This document identifies 25+ real-world multi-wavelength astronomical datasets
suitable for training ML models to classify AGN versus star-forming galaxies.

ALL DATASETS ARE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE.

TOP RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. SDSS DR16 multi-wavelength crossmatch (~30,000 sources, 98% ML accuracy)
2. COSMOS2020 + X-ray/radio cross-matches (1.7M sources, 30+ bands)
3. eRASS1 AGN catalog (900,000+ X-ray sources with ML classifications)
4. Chandra Deep Field South 7Ms (1,008 sources, 98.4% multi-wavelength IDs)

CONCLUSION: Synthetic data NOT required. Real-world datasets provide
50,000-100,000+ labeled sources with complete multi-wavelength coverage.

================================================================================
1. X-RAY SURVEYS WITH MULTI-WAVELENGTH COUNTERPARTS
================================================================================

1.1 Chandra Deep Field South 7Ms (EXCELLENT)
    Sample: 1,008 X-ray sources, 992 (98.4%) with multi-wavelength IDs
    Wavelengths: X-ray, Optical (HST), NIR, Mid-IR, Far-IR, Radio
    Access: https://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/all/chandfs7ms.html

1.2 eROSITA All-Sky Survey DR1 (EXCELLENT - PRIMARY RECOMMENDED)
    Sample: >900,000 X-ray sources, ML classifications available
    Wavelengths: X-ray (eROSITA), Optical/NIR (Legacy Survey DR10)
    Access: https://erosita.mpe.mpg.de/dr1/

1.3 Chandra Source Catalog 2.1 (EXCELLENT)
    Sample: ~400,000 X-ray sources
    Wavelengths: X-ray, Optical (Pan-STARRS), NIR (2MASS), Gaia
    Access: https://cxc.cfa.harvard.edu/csc/

1.4 Chandra/XMM-COSMOS (EXCELLENT)
    Sample: ~2,000 X-ray sources
    Wavelengths: Full COSMOS multi-wavelength (UV-radio)
    Access: https://cosmos.astro.caltech.edu/

1.5 eROSITA eFEDS (EXCELLENT)
    Sample: 22,079 AGN
    Access: https://erosita.mpe.mpg.de/edr/

1.6 XMM-Newton 4XMM-DR14
    Sample: ~810,000 X-ray sources
    Access: http://xmmssc.irap.omp.eu/

================================================================================
2. SDSS SPECTROSCOPIC SAMPLES WITH MULTI-WAVELENGTH PHOTOMETRY
================================================================================

2.1 SDSS DR16 Multi-Wavelength Crossmatch (EXCELLENT - PRIMARY)
    Sample: ~30,000 galaxies
    Wavelengths: UV (GALEX), Optical (SDSS + spectroscopy), X-ray, IR (WISE)
    ML Performance: 98% accuracy demonstrated
    Access: Contact authors (Dalya et al. 2025) | SDSS DR16
    USE CASE: START HERE - explicitly designed for AGN vs. SFG classification

2.2 MPA-JHU SDSS Catalog (EXCELLENT)
    Sample: ~900,000 galaxies with BPT classifications
    Wavelengths: Optical (SDSS), can augment with WISE/GALEX/X-ray
    Access: https://wwwmpa.mpa-garching.mpg.de/SDSS/

2.3 SDSS Value-Added Catalogs
    SPIDERS: ~10,000+ X-ray AGN
    MaNGA: Hundreds with IFU spectroscopy
    Access: https://www.sdss4.org/dr17/data_access/value-added-catalogs/

================================================================================
3.RADIO SURVEY CATALOGS WITH OPTICAL/IR CROSS-MATCHES
================================================================================

3.1 LOFAR LoTSS DR2 (EXCELLENT - Radio-Selected)
    Sample: 4,116,934 radio sources, ~85% with optical/IR IDs
    Wavelengths: Radio (LOFAR 144 MHz), Optical (Pan-STARRS), IR (WISE)
    Access: https://lofar-surveys.org/

3.2 VLA-COSMOS 3 GHz (EXCELLENT)
    Sample: 10,830 radio sources, 7,903 classified
    Wavelengths: Radio, Full COSMOS multi-wavelength
    Access: https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/COSMOS/

================================================================================
4. DEEP FIELD SURVEYS WITH COMPLETE MULTI-WAVELENGTH COVERAGE
================================================================================

4.1 COSMOS2020 Catalog (EXCELLENT - PRIMARY)
    Sample: ~1.7 million sources, 30+ photometric bands
    Wavelengths: UV-Optical-NIR-Mid-IR-Far-IR-X-ray-Radio
    Access: https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/COSMOS/
    USE CASE: One of the best datasets, cross-match with X-ray/radio for labels

4.2 GOODS-South CANDELS (EXCELLENT - Validation)
    Sample: ~35,000-40,000 sources
    Wavelengths: Complete UV-radio coverage, deep X-ray
    Access: https://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/candels/

4.3 GOODS-North CANDELS
    Sample: ~30,000-35,000 sources with SHARDS spectroscopy
    Access: https://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/candels/

================================================================================
5. ADDITIONAL DATASETS
================================================================================

5.1 AllWISE AGN Catalog
    Sample: 4.5M AGN candidates (R90 catalog, 90% reliability)
    Wavelengths: Mid-IR (WISE), requires cross-matching
    Access: https://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/all/allwiseagn.html

5.2 Million Quasar Catalog
    Sample: >1 million spectroscopically confirmed AGN
    Access: https://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/w3browse/all/milliquas.html

================================================================================
6. PUBLIC ML CHALLENGE DATASETS - NOT SUITABLE
================================================================================

Galaxy Zoo / Kaggle: NOT RECOMMENDED (morphology, not AGN vs. SFG)
UCI Repository: NOT APPLICABLE (no AGN datasets)

================================================================================
7. SYNTHETIC DATA JUSTIFICATION
================================================================================

CONCLUSION: SYNTHETIC DATA NOT REQUIRED

Why Real Data is Sufficient:
- Large samples available: 1.7M (COSMOS2020), 900K+ (eRASS1), 4M+ (LOFAR)
- Complete multi-wavelength coverage: UV-optical-NIR-mid-IR-far-IR-X-ray-radio
- Reliable classifications: spectroscopy, X-ray, SED fitting
- Public accessibility: all major datasets publicly available

Estimated Combined Sample:
- Training: 50,000-100,000+ labeled sources
- Validation: 5,000-10,000+
- Test: 5,000-10,000+

THIS IS MORE THAN SUFFICIENT FOR DEEP LEARNING.

================================================================================
8. PRIORITY RANKING
================================================================================

Priority 1 (START HERE):

================================================================================

================================================================================
